Posts.Content: yes, I had terrible cording. I had FEC in my right arm 5 times via a cannula and it got so bad the had to use the left arm (the side of my op) for my 6th. It did eventually die down but it took a good 6 months or so. I had a heat pad wrapped around my arm to help at the time.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: yes, I had terrible cording. I had FEC in my right arm 5 times via a cannula and it got so bad the had to use the left arm (the side of my op) for my 6th. It did eventually die down but it took a good 6 months or so. I had a heat pad wrapped around my arm to help at the time.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzie I've met some wonderful people who've helped with my cancer. It has also brought closer relationships that had grown apart. For that I'm very grateful. I think it has also made my relationship with my wife even closer. We've been through some tough times together these last 12 months. I really don't know what I would have done without her. Thanks for the positive thread. :) Mike
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: I found that having the heated blanket around my arm when having FEC was a great relief. If you can't see it, ask for it. Hope it eases for you. Mike
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: I've just worked out a way to share my 18 week diary. It's in a blog. http://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/fec_chemotherapy_6_session_diary/archive/2015/05/16/my-18-week-fec-treatment-diary.aspx Hope someone will find it useful. Mike xx
Posts.Title: My FEC Diary

Posts.Content: It's the same for guys too. Only just getting any kind of libido back after a year of ops and chemo. My wife has been amazing through all this. Take your time, everyone moves to their own pace. Hope it all works out for you. :) Mike xx
Posts.Title: I need to ask a very personal question?

Posts.Content: 33 years of going out together. This time last year this was our day together: "Thursday 26th June: DAY 15 of the 4th Chemo Session Woke feeling very sick and nauseous. Phone helpline and went in again. Had Ondansetron in an IV. Had bloods checked, ecg and an examination by a doctor. Spent about 4 hours in total getting looked at. Came home and went for a walk. Started to improve late evening. Broken sleep." Not the most romantic of days! :) I'm soo glad Tina was there with me through all of my treatment. She deserves much better days in the future. Life does get better. Stay strong everyone. Mike and Tina xxx
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: Thanks so much! Both in work today but we're going to Greece for a week on Wednesday :) WoooHooo!!!
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: Thank you all. :)
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: That's great news, Pat. Although I thought the same about claiming back some tax :)
Posts.Title: Tax reduction

Posts.Content: Groan!! :)
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: Splott isn't too bad a place to live. It has gotten a lot better since I was a young boy. That's great! Is she enjoying working there? It's such a large hospital, so easy to get lost. Mike
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy I can give you a positive. Mastectomy in Feb 2014, Chemo on the 10th June 2014, treatment finished end of July. Check up this Feb and I was given the all clear. It can happen. Take care Mike xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Yes it was. :) It is a beautiful day in Cardiff. I work 20 miles north in Merthyr Tydfil and the sun even makes Merthyr look nice :)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Yeay :)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Diolch/Thank you, Wendy :)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Hi Jess I've just emailed you Mike
Posts.Title: Looking for men who have had breast cancer to help us

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen My GP could not have been less interested if he tried. Just go as slow as you want was his sage advice. No plan, no schedule, no replacement,weaker drugs to replace the doses I'm on now. Just as well we are proactive isn't it. :) Mike
Posts.Title: Update on my jaw pain, stress and drugs situation.

Posts.Content: Hi Alison Thanks.  How are you doing? Kicking ass I hope :)
Posts.Title: Update on my jaw pain, stress and drugs situation.

Posts.Content: That's great news. Take good care of yourself after your op. Feet up!! xx
Posts.Title: Update on my jaw pain, stress and drugs situation.

Posts.Content: Hi folks As some of you may have seen I developed a problem with my jaw. I've had a lot of pain with it over the last six months. At first we thought it was due to the Tamoxifen, but it turned out that wasn't the cause after coming off it for 8 weeks.  The cause was stress during the chemo phase of my treatment. I ground and clenched my teeth so much that it put my jaw muscles under so much tension that now, after visiting a jaw specialist, have been told I have cramp.  Good news is that it doesn't need any surgery. The best thing to ease it is to apply heat 4 times a day. Bad news is that I've now got to ease myself off tramadol, gabapentin and lorazapam. I've been on these to help with the pain and I've been told, and had some experience myself that coming off them is very difficult. We're seeing my GP tonight with a plan to gradually come off them. All this is due to being stressed. If there's anything you can do, or are offered that relieves stress, please grab it with both hands. It'll really help you in the long run. Good luck with the battle and take good care of yourselves. Mike xxx
Posts.Title: Update on my jaw pain, stress and drugs situation.

Posts.Content: Hi Jim. I had breast cancer and FEC in 6 sessions. Sleep I didn't really have a problem with as I just slept when and where I needed it. It didn't happen all night, so I just went online or did some sudokus. I can try to answer any other queries you have. Like I said I had breast cancer, a mastectomy on my left side. FEC chemo x 6 sessions, 3 weeks apart. Please don't hesitate to ask. Best wishes with your treatment Mike
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: That's a good tip about the non-foaming toothpaste. I used Sarakan but could only find it online.
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: Hi Jim. FEC is the name of the type of chemotheraphy I was given. FEC Chemotherapy description I finished treatment end of July last year, slowly recovering at the moment. I had the all clear in Feb. Yes, they took a big chunk of chest away. I have a dent now! :) I was offered reconstruction, but they said for all the trouble it took it was hardly worth it for a man. They would do it if I really wanted it. All the best Mike
Posts.Title: Chemo Survival Kit – Version 3 – 8 April 2015 - please read and contribute...

Posts.Content: I had that bitter taste all through my 6 FEC sessions. I had a large packet of boots low calorie mints to help me through it. It does go away after. I did find that beer tasted very different and I couldn't drink it anymore!! Thankfully after six months off chemo I can drink it again. :) Good luck with your treatment. Mike
Posts.Title: Horrible Taste in Mouth

Posts.Content: My neighbour said no after three sessions of chemo. She couldn't take anymore and suggested I do the same when I was struggling. I'm so glad I didn't listen now. I must admit it was very tempting. I did have one very, very dark and bleak Sunday when I talked about stopping with my wife. It was good to get those feeling out in the open and once I actually said the words out loud, I knew I didn't want to stop. I really wouldn't want to be worrying about it coming back and be my fault for stopping the treatment.  The last FEC was a great relief. Keep strong all you brave ladies. Much love and respect. Mike
Posts.Title: Horrible Taste in Mouth

Posts.Content: I've become a Sudoko junkie since starting my treatment. Anything that exercises your mind is worth trying.
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hi Jai Mine was a definite lump and even then I had to really persuade my GPs to take it seriously. I would get myself straight down there if I was you and get them to thoroughly check it out. Good luck Mike
Posts.Title: Male breast cancer query..

Posts.Content: and other than a few psychological issues I'm here to tell the tale. All my thanks go to my wife who has been amazing through all this. Such strength! and of course to the wonderful NHS staff at both the Velindre Cancer Hospital, Cardiff and Llandough Hospital, Penarth.  Stay strong folks. Mike :-) xxx
Posts.Title: My last FEC treatment was a year ago today!

Posts.Content: Thanks folks. It's always inspirational to read positive stories and I'm just pleased I was able to share mine. Best wishes to you all. xx
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: It has been 2.5 years since my chemo ended and yesterday was a big moment for me, returning to competitive running. I've still a long way to go to get to anywhere near where I was, but that really doesn't matter. It doesn't look like it, but I am enjoying myself :) Good luck to you all going through your various stages of treatment. Mike xx
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: You WILL get there. I've been running for the last 6 months, gradually building up my strength. Don't rush it, I was really amazed how much having all this treatment takes it out of you. Slow and steady. Have you a local parkrun? Good luck, and thanks for the best wishes. :)
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: Congratulations! Enjoy your future :) Mike xx
Posts.Title: survivor

Posts.Content: I wrote mine in a simple note/word program and then copied and pasted the whole thing into the blog section here once I had finished writing it. https://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/ You can, of course just start a blog here from scratch.
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: I kept one and uploaded it to the blog area of this website https://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/fec_chemotherapy_6_session_diary/archive/2015/05/16/my-18-week-fec-treatment-diary I appreciate it's from a male breast cancer perspective, but there might be things there of use.
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Sorry I can't be of any real help. I found mine really early and it was just a case of surgery and FEC chemo to make absolutely sure. It hadn't spread anywhere, luckily. I'm so sorry your father in law is having to go through this.  Hope you can get the info and support you need. Mike
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer and Clueless!

Posts.Content: They did the blood test alongside a head scan. I've been having headaches for the last three months which have been getting slowly worse. I get the result from the head scan next week. I think all my post treatment symptoms are down to stress. Once all my results are in and hopefully (I have no reason to believe otherwise) they are clear I might start to relax. We (my wife and I) are looking at some relaxation techniques, maybe acupuncture etc but definitely a two week sunny holiday somewhere. I was diagnosed with StageOne Breast Cancer February last year and finished my chemo last July. It's just getting my brain to believe the good news and stop worrying! :) Thanks for replies
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers

Posts.Content: Now that's obviously good news and I was so pleased when the nurse told me I forgot to ask her this: "What cancers did they check for?" Does anybody know? I had male breast cancer and I'm coming up to my first anniversary of my operation on the 11th Feb. Any information would be appreciated.
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers

Posts.Content: I've mentioned this is another thread but happy to repeat myself in here :) I had the all clear in February this year. I had breast cancer, found lump under my nipple (left side). I had a mastectomy then 6 courses of FEC. Finished all my treatment in July last year. It hasn't all been plain sailing since. Lots of mental problems, feeling like it'll come back etc. I'm still having a very nauseous feeling in my tummy all the time but I'm putting that down to the cocktail of drugs I'm still on. I've had jaw pain from grinding my teeth when I was undergoing chemo, but that's slowly beginning to get better. But to be honest, that's nothing in the grand scheme of things. Cancer free sounds good. Best of luck and take care of yourselves. Mike  xx
Posts.Title: Positive outcomes ...

Posts.Content: Thank you. Just my first year scan on the 18th to go now. It was odd seeing the nurses trying to find enough tissue to give me a mammogram at my diagnosis. I think I've lost some weight since then!! :)
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers

Posts.Content: More good news. Brain Scan came back clear. :) xxx
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers

Posts.Content: Thank you. No explanation yet. We're going to wait until after the 18th. Once I get the all clear I'm hoping I'll start to relax. If not, then I'll probably need a mouth guard or similar to stop me clenching my teeth. It's obviously stress related so there's lots of paths to go down to get me relaxed. I'm pretty much open to anything that helps. Mike
Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers
